items.title: ProtocolError when trying to save RGB numpy array as png
items.body:
Hi, thank you for maintaining png! I was trying png as a way to replace Pillow with a lightweight dependency, but I stumbled upon an error which I have a hard time understanding. What I'm trying to do is to convert numpy arrays to png b64 strings (here I saved to a file for a simpler example but I get the same error)
```python
import numpy as np                                                               
img = np.random.randint(256, size=(512, 512, 3), dtype=np.uint8)                 
import png                                                                       
png.from_array(img, mode='RGB').save('tmp.png')           
```
Output
```python                       
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ProtocolError                             Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-eb627b832095> in <module>
----> 1 png.from_array(img, mode='RGB').save('tmp.png')

~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/png.py in save(self, file)
   1278 
   1279         with open(file, 'wb') as fd:
-> 1280             w.write(fd, self.rows)
   1281 
   1282     def write(self, file):

~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/png.py in write(self, outfile, rows)
    666             return self.write_array(outfile, a)
    667 
--> 668         nrows = self.write_passes(outfile, check_rows(rows))
    669         if nrows != self.height:
    670             raise ProtocolError(

~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/png.py in write_passes(self, outfile, rows)
    700             rows = unpack_rows(rows)
    701 
--> 702         return self.write_packed(outfile, rows)
    703 
    704     def write_packed(self, outfile, rows):

~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/png.py in write_packed(self, outfile, rows)
    732         data = bytearray()
    733 
--> 734         for i, row in enumerate(rows):
    735             # Add "None" filter type.
    736             # Currently, it's essential that this filter type be used

~/.local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/png.py in check_rows(rows)
    658                     raise ProtocolError(
    659                         "Expected %d values but got %d values, in row %d" %
--> 660                         (vpr, len(row), i))
    661                 yield row
    662 

ProtocolError: ProtocolError: Expected 510 values but got 512 values, in row 0
```

items.title: In the documentation, "A ramp" example is broken on the live site
items.body:
In [PyPNG Code Examples](https://pythonhosted.org/pypng/ex.html) as of Jan 14 2020, the first example looks like this:

```py
import png
f = open('ramp.png', 'wb')      # binary mode is important
w = png.Writer(255, 1, greyscale=True)
w.write(f, [range(256)])
f.close()
```

Screenshot:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/59632/72329934-45507700-367b-11ea-8ee4-b7362526fa3f.png)

However, this example is wrong. `png.Writer` should get `256` as it first argument, but this example passes in `255`. The resulting error was hard to understand:

```
>>> w.write(f, [range(256)])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/png.py", line 670, in write
    nrows = self.write_passes(outfile, check_rows(rows))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/png.py", line 704, in write_passes
    return self.write_packed(outfile, rows)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/png.py", line 736, in write_packed
    for i, row in enumerate(rows):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/png.py", line 662, in check_rows
    (vpr, len(row), i))
png.ProtocolError: ProtocolError: Expected 255 values but got 256 value, in row 0
```

However, when I tried to submit a fix to the documentation, it's apparently already fixed!

https://github.com/drj11/pypng/blob/b4d31df682522ffcb9834aa9a1bcae95ac30bd14/man/ex.rst#a-ramp

So I suspect that the live version of https://pythonhosted.org/pypng/ex.html is out of date. Would it be possible to rebuild and redeploy it?

How can I get the png raw data convert from an array?
Then I can base64 it for future use.

Thanks a lot.

items.title: from_array to accept 3D-arrays
items.body:
the only change would take I think, is: 
```
if a.ndim == 3:
    a = a.reshape((a.shape[0], -1))
```
somewhere in `from_array()`, before grabbing the first row in a
Cheers

items.title: Transposing numpy array input causes failure in write()
items.body:
Transposing the numpy input array causes an error when I try to save the file.

```python
# Normally it works:
>>> a = np.array([[0, 1], [2, 3]]).astype(np.int8)
>>> i = png.from_array(a, mode='L')
>>> i.save('/tmp/i.png')

# Transposing breaks it:
>>> a_trans = np.transpose(a)
>>> i_trans = png.from_array(a_trans, mode='L')
>>> i_trans.save('/tmp/i_trans.png')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/chuck/anaconda3/envs/hubmap/lib/python3.6/site-packages/png.py", line 1371, in save
    w.write(file, self.rows)
  File "/Users/chuck/anaconda3/envs/hubmap/lib/python3.6/site-packages/png.py", line 648, in write
    nrows = self.write_passes(outfile, check_rows(rows))
  File "/Users/chuck/anaconda3/envs/hubmap/lib/python3.6/site-packages/png.py", line 682, in write_passes
    return self.write_packed(outfile, rows)
  File "/Users/chuck/anaconda3/envs/hubmap/lib/python3.6/site-packages/png.py", line 723, in write_packed
    data.extend(row)
TypeError: can't set bytearray slice from numpy.ndarray

# Dump to array and reload is a work-around:
>>> a_trans_wrapped = np.array(a_trans.tolist()).astype(np.int8)
>>> i_trans_wrapped = png.from_array(a_trans_wrapped, mode='L')
>>> i_trans_wrapped.save('/tmp/i_trans_wrapped.png')
```

```
$ pip show pypng
Name: pypng
Version: 0.0.19
```

items.title: Compatibility with Pythonista on iOS devices?
GPG signatures for source validation
items.body:
As we all know, today more than ever before, it is crucial to be able to trust our computing environments. One of the main difficulties that package maintainers of Linux distributions face, is the difficulty to verify the authenticity and the integrity of the source code.

The Arch Linux team would appreciate it if you would provide us GPG signatures in order to verify easily and quickly of your source code releases.

**Overview of the required tasks:**
* [ ] Please [create and/or use a 4096-bit RSA keypair](https://wiki.archlinux.org/index.php/GnuPG#Create_key_pair) for the file signing
* The key may be used for [email encryption](https://www.enigmail.net/index.php/en/) too
* Keep your key secret, use a strong unique passphrase for the key
* [ ] Upload the public key to a key server
* [ ] [Sign every new commit by default](https://help.github.com/articles/signing-commits-using-gpg/)
* [ ] [Sign new tags](https://help.github.com/articles/signing-tags-using-gpg/)
* Verify the Github Release tarball download against your local source
* [ ] [Sign Github Release tarballs](https://wiki.debian.org/Creating%20signed%20GitHub%20releases)

**Additional Information:**
* https://help.github.com/categories/gpg/
* https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Tools-Signing-Your-Work
* https://www.qubes-os.org/doc/verifying-signatures/
* https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/security/encrypt-in-transit/why-https

Thanks.

items.title: Chunk IDAT too short for required 65524 octets
items.body:
`pypng` complains about chunk IDAT too short for required octets.

The code that raises the exception could be found there:

https://github.com/drj11/pypng/blob/f5c4c76d81093b6c3f39f83b203f6832c496c110/code/png.py#L1386

actually is it really a problem? I wonder whether this check is required.

pngcheck utility doesn't complain about the same file:

```
pngcheck  -vvv idat_too_short.png 
File: idat_too_short.png (64986 bytes)
  chunk IHDR at offset 0x0000c, length 13
    260 x 300 image, 8-bit palette, non-interlaced
  chunk PLTE at offset 0x00025, length 768: 256 palette entries
  chunk IDAT at offset 0x00331, length 64149
    zlib: deflated, 32K window, default compression
  chunk IEND at offset 0x0fdd2, length 0
No errors detected in idat_too_short.png (4 chunks, 16.7% compression).
```

also the file could be opened e.g. in firefox or Gnome Image Viewer.

items.title: pHYs information is not added to the "meta" dict
items.body: The "pHYs" chunk is read but the information is not added to the meta dict returned by `png.Reader.read()`. Users could ask the reader for the information, but IMO it should be added to the meta dict.

items.title: Can open an image from url but not if it is download local?
items.body:
Python 3.4 x64 on windows. pypng-0.0.18

**What I did:**

> > > f=urllib.request.urlopen('http://www.schaik.com/pngsuite/basn0g02.png')
> > > r=png.Reader(f)
> > > r.read()
> > > (32, 32, <map object at 0x000000000341D358>, {'size': (32, 32), 'gamma': 1.0, 'a
> > > lpha': False, 'greyscale': True, 'planes': 1, 'bitdepth': 2, 'interlace': 0})
> > > f1=open(r'e:\basn0g02.png')
> > > r1=png.Reader(f1)
> > > r1.read()
> > > Traceback (most recent call last):
> > >   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
> > >   File "d:\python34\lib\site-packages\png.py", line 1950, in read
> > >     self.preamble(lenient=lenient)
> > >   File "d:\python34\lib\site-packages\png.py", line 1740, in preamble
> > >     self.validate_signature()
> > >   File "d:\python34\lib\site-packages\png.py", line 1725, in validate_signature
> > >     self.signature = self.file.read(8)
> > >   File "d:\python34\lib\encodings\cp1252.py", line 23, in decode
> > >     return codecs.charmap_decode(input,self.errors,decoding_table)[0]
> > > UnicodeDecodeError: 'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x8f in position 74: chara
> > > cter maps to <undefined>

**What I saw:**
A download-to-local image is openable fine by other local application but not by the similar pypng code. Weird.    File "d:\python34\lib\encodings\cp1252.py", line 23, in decode
    return codecs.charmap_decode(input,self.errors,decoding_table)[0]
UnicodeDecodeError: 'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x8f in position 74: character maps to <undefined>

items.title: Python3 type mismatch on alpha='force'
items.body:
This code, when running on python 3.5.2 (the one I have):

```
f=open(pngfile,'rb')
image = png.Reader(f)
palette = image.palette(alpha='force')
```

Gives the following error:

```
    palette = image.palette(alpha='force')
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/png.py", line 2011, in palette
    trns = array('B', self.trns or '')
```

items.title: Animated PNGs?
items.body: Didn't find mention of this in the documentation, but is there any way to get the rows from frames of animated PNGs past the first?

items.title: Why pass the 'info' dictionary to from_array?
items.body: Why pass the 'info' dictionary to from_array, when it is not used directly? The only thing it does is to check, if the information is the same in array + mode compared to the dict. It would greatly simplify maintains and use of the code, if the user had to do the necessary checks.

items.title: Documentation for pngReader.read doesn't identify return 4-tuple item names
items.body: Mostly this is an issue I had distinguishing whether the first two variables of the four-tuple were width, or height.

items.title: Typo in chunk(self, seek=None, lenient=False): Unknown variable
items.body:
See: https://github.com/drj11/pypng/blob/master/code/png.py#L1437

``` python
            if len(checksum) != 4:
                raise ValueError('Chunk %s too short for checksum.', tag)
```

should probably changed to:

``` python
            if len(checksum) != 4:
                raise ValueError('Chunk %s too short for checksum.' % type)
```

items.body: Should be simples to do, right?

items.title: Question: is there any way to now bitdepth per channel?
items.body: Question: is there any way to now bitdepth per channel?

items.title: Incorrect handling of filter type 0
items.body:
According to http://www.w3.org/TR/2003/REC-PNG-20031110/#9Filters, filter type 0 should not change the bytes.

On line 1556 in png.py, the first filter type is _None_, which causes TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not callable .

A possible fix is to change it to something like _lambda *args: None_. Also, the test for invalid filter type in previous code should also be updated

items.title: No help is given if you write the wrong number of pixels.
items.body:
For example

```
python -c 'import png;w=png.Writer(width=4,height=1,greyscale=True);w.write(open("g.png", "w"), [[1,111,222]])'
```

Produces no warnings, but writes a file which is not a valid PNG. Reading this file in using `png.py` gives:

```
drj$ ./png.py -r < g.png > /dev/null
FormatError: Wrong size for decompressed IDAT chunk.
```

(which is not brilliantly informative, but is actually correct).

Similarly if too many pixels are supplied.

Supplying the wrong number of rows does seem to be detected.

items.title: OverflowError when using pypng.Writer
items.body:
Only intermittently, not using any randomized values. I'm unsure what it could be besides a bug in pypng.

Here's my stack trace:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "terragen.py", line 20, in <module>
    gen = Terragen2(size=512, verbose=True)
  File "/home/main/www/project/pyserver/app/gen/main.py", line 37, in __init__
    self.heightmap.save()
  File "/home/main/www/project/pyserver/app/gen/main.py", line 113, in save
    make_png(p, 'heightmap', self.size)
  File "/home/main/www/project/pyserver/app/gen/main.py", line 24, in make_png
    w.write(f, data)
  File "/home/main/virt_env/virt1/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/png.py", line 642, in write
    nrows = self.write_passes(outfile, rows)
  File "/home/main/virt_env/virt1/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/png.py", line 796, in write_passes
    extend(row)
OverflowError: unsigned byte integer is less than minimum
```

This is how I am using it:

``` python
# where data is a 2D list of numbers from 1 to 255
# where size is integer image size
f = open('%s/%s.png' % (OUTPUT_PATH, name), 'wb')
w = png.Writer(size, size)
w.write(f, data)
f.close()
```

items.title: Pyximport.install() can break the build of projects using pypng
items.body: I had the problem that after importing pypng into my project, none of my cython code worked anymore. It was caused by pyximport, which is setup in png.py. When pyximport.install() is called, it takes over compilation of cython code for the whole process, not just the file it was called in. So instead of my cython code being compiled using the correct flags that I specified in setup.py, it was being compiled using the default parameters by pyximport, which broke things.

items.title: Documentaton, missing note
items.body:
In docs [here](http://pythonhosted.org/pypng/png.html#png.from_array) there is a note missing:

```
The use of the term *3-dimensional* is for marketing purposes
only.  It doesn't actually work.  Please bear with us.  Meanwhile
enjoy the complimentary snacks (on request) and please use a
2-dimensional array.
```

items.title: Support for tEXt chunks
items.body:
The old issue [#65](https://code.google.com/p/pypng/issues/detail?id=65) seems to have been forgotten, unless I've missed something.

Any chance of getting that patched applied?  (It still applies pretty cleanly, only a single hunk fails and it is trivial to fix manually.)

items.title: Add 2-dimension and 3-dimension arrays to the note about pixel formats
items.body:
http://pythonhosted.org/pypng/png.html#a-note-on-formats - speaks about:
- BRFP
- FRFP
- BRBP

http://pythonhosted.org/pypng/png.html#png.from_array - speaks about:
[row structure]
- 2-dimensional array
- 3-dimensional array
  [pixel structure]
  - L (level)
  - LA (level alpha)
  - RGB
  - RGBA

The notes on formats and from_array reference can be generalized and merged. The format note talks basically about [row structure] - it does not provide any visual reference for [pixel structure] except mentioning somewhere deep that it can be RGBA, LA or fourth (!) `packed` format. When I say `visual reference` I mean separate paragraph that looks like picture - it has visual structure as a list or table - not just plain text. I find from_array reference description much more clear and up to the point.

This basically was born out of the observation that a person reading pypng docs for the first time is most likely looking for answers:
- Is pixel in pypng the same as pixel I know?
- How the pixel that I know is represented in pypng?

Luckily, the RGBA format is familiar to everybody, but what about grayscale? For example, I made my image from_array using 2DL format, but how I should modify it now? Do I have to convert my algorithm to convert everything to RGBA values?

The really good point of current documentation is that explanation is done by example. The only awesome enhancement that can be made are a few pictures to spice up the text a bit (like Scapy docs do).

To summarize, this is an enhancement proposal to describe pypng from the pixel-centric perspective. =)

items.title: download_url in setup.py is wrong
items.body:
The download url in setup.py links to Google Code, this makes the current download url registered in pypi to be:

```
http://pypng.googlecode.com/files/pypng-0.0.14.tar.gz
```

This link doesn't exist and it causes

```
easy_install pypng
```

to fail

items.title: The filter "up" doesn't add a byte to indicate that the scanline is encoded with "up".
items.body:
The filter (which afaics is not used) does not prepend the output array with "2", and all the other filters prepend its output with its filter type.

I think this is a bug, but you know the PNG format way better that I do and this may be legal.

Cheers,

items.title: Palette processing is annoying.
items.body: The palette should appear in the info dict when a PNG has a palette, so that it can then be passed straight to Writer.write to create a palette image.

items.title: Reader.iterboxed.asvalues doesn't work in python3 for low bit depth
items.body:
this line
shifts = map(self.bitdepth.**mul**, reversed(range(spb)))
needs to be
shifts = list(map(self.bitdepth.**mul**, reversed(range(spb))))

because you read through shifts multiple times in the following loop, which doesn't work with a map object.

items.title: Document Reader metadata a bit?
items.body: While pypng is nice to play with, it would be nice if Reader().preamble() doc pointed to metadata descrpition and metadata description mentioned that it is not available in reader oject until preamble is called. Is it worth it?

items.title: __version__ is useless after moving to Git
items.body: curl download doesn't substitute version for the file, which is quite inconvenient for any kind of maintenance.
